editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The fair maid of the West. Or, a girl worth gold. The first part. As it was lately acted before the King and Queen, with approved liking. By the Queen's majesty's comedians.
London, printed for Richard Royston, and are to be sold at his shop in ivy lane. 1631.

div.head: To the much worthy, and my most respected, John Othow, esquire, counsellor at law, in the noble society of Gray inn.
div.p:
Excuse this my boldness, (I entreat you) and let it pass under the title of my love and respect, long devoted unto you; of which, if I endeavour to present the world with a due acknowledgement without the sordid expectation of reward, or servile imputation of flattery, I hope it will be the rather accepted. I must ingenuously acknowledge, a weightier argument would have better suited with your grave employment; but there are retirements necessarily belonging to all the labours of the body and brain: if in any such cessation, you will deign to cast an eye upon this weak and unpolished poem, I shall receive it as a courtesy from you, much exceeding
any merit in me, (My good meaning only accepted.) Thus wishing you healthful ability in body, untroubled content in mind: with the happy fruition of both the temporal felicities of the world present, and the eternal blessedness of the life future; I still remain as ever,

closer.signed: Yours, most affectionately devoted, Thomas Heywood.

div.head: To the reader.
div.p: Courteous reader, my plays have not been exposed to the public view of the world in numerous sheets, and a large volume; but singly (As thou seest) with great modesty, and small noise. These comedies, bearing the title of, the fair maid of the West: if they prove but as gracious in thy private reading, as they were plausible in the public acting, I shall not much doubt of their success. Nor need they (I hope) much fear a rugged and censorious brow from thee, on whom the greatest and best in the kingdom, have vouchsafed to smile. I hold it no necessity to trouble thee with the argument of the story, the matter itself lying so plainly before thee in acts and scenes, without any deviations, or winding indents.

lg.l: Peruse it through, and thou mayst find in it,
Some mirth, some matter, and, perhaps, some wit.

closer.signed: He that would study thy content, T. H.

list.item: Two sea captains.
Mr. carol, a gentleman.
Mr. Spencer. By mr. Michael Bowyer.
Captain Goodlack, Spencer's friend; by mr. Rich. Perkins.
Two vintner's boys.
Bess Bridges, the fair maid of the West; by Hugh clerk.
Mr. Forset, a gentleman; by Christoph. Goad.
Mr. Ruffman, a swaggering gentleman; by William Shearlock.
Clem, a drawer of wine under Bess bridges; by mr. William Robinson.
Three sailors ▪ a surgeon.
A kitchen maid; by mr. Anthony Furner.
The mayor of Foy, an alderman, and a servant.
A Spanish Cap. by. C. Goad
An English merchant; by Rob. Axle.
Mullisheg, K. of Fez, by mr. Will. Allen.
Bashaw Alcade; by mr. Wilbraham.
Bashaw Joffer.
Two Spanish captains.
A French merchant.
An Italian merchant.
A chorus.
The Earl of Essex going to Cales: the mayor of Plymouth, with petitioners, mutes, personated.

lg.l: Among the Grecians there were annual feasts,
To which none were invited as chief guests,
Save princes and their wives. Amongst the men,
There was no argument disputed then,
But who best governed: and (As't did appear)
He was esteemed sole sovereign for that year.
The Queens and ladies argued at that time,
For virtue and for beauty which was prime,
And she had the high honour. Two here be,
For beauty one, the other majesty,
Most worthy (Did that custom still persever)
Not for one year, but to be sovereigns ever.

div.head: The fair maid of the West: or, a girl worth gold.
div.stage: Enter two captains, and mr. Carrol.

sp.speaker: 1. Capt.
sp.p: When puts my lord to sea?

sp.speaker: 2. Capt.
sp.p: When the wind's fair.

lg.l: Resolve me I entreat, can you not guess
The purpose of this voyage?
Most men think
The fleet's bound for the lands.
Nay, 'tis like.
The great success at Cales under the conduct
Of such a noble general, hath put heart
Into the English: they are all on fire
To purchase from the Spaniard. If their carracks
Come deeply laden, we shall tug with them
For golden spoil.

sp.speaker: 2. Capt.
sp.p: O, were it come to that!

lg.l: How Plymouth swells with gallants ▪ how the streets
Glister with gold! You cannot meet a man
But tricked in scarf and feather, that it seems
As if the pride of England's gallantry
Were harboured here. It doth appear ( methinks )
A very court of soldiers.
It doth so.
Where shall we dine today?

sp.speaker: 2. Capt.
sp.p: At the next tavern by; there's the best wine,

lg.l: And the best wench, Bess bridges, she's the flower
Of Plymouth held: the castle needs no bush,
Her beauty draws to them more gallant customers
Then all the signs ith' town else.
A sweet lass,
If I have any judgement.
Now in troth
I think she's honest.
Honest, and live there?
What, in a public tavern, where's such confluence
Of lusty and brave gallants? Honest said you?

sp.speaker: 2. Capt.
sp.p: I vow she is for me.

sp.speaker: 1. Capt.
sp.p: For all, I think. I'm sure she's wondrous modest.

lg.l: But withal
Exceeding affable.

sp.speaker: 2 Capt.
sp.p: An argument that she's not proud.

sp.speaker: Carr.
sp.p: No, were she proud, she'd fall.

lg.l: Well, she's a most attractive adamant,
Her very beauty hath upheld that house,
And gained her master much.
That adamant
Shall for this time draw me to, we'll dine there.

sp.speaker: 2. Capt.
sp.p: No better motion: come to the castle then.
sp.stage: Enter m. Spencer, and Capt. Goodlack.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: What, to the old house still?

lg.l: Canst blame me, captain,
Believe me, I was never surprised till now,
Or caught upon the sudden.
Pray resolve me,
Why being a gentleman of fortunes, means,
And well reserved, will you adventure thus
A doubtful voyage, when only such as I
Born to no other fortunes then my sword
should seek abroad for pillage.
Pillage, captain?
No, 'tis for honour; and the brave society
Of all these shining gallants that attend
The great l. general, drew me hither first:
No hope of gain or spoil.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Ay, but what draws you to this house so oft?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: As if thou knewest it not.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: What, Bess?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Even she.

lg.l: Come, I must tell you, you forget yourself,
One of your birth and breeding, thus to dote
Upon a tanner's daughter: why, her father
Sold hides in Somersetshire, and being trade-fallen,
Sent her to service.
Prithee speak no more,
Thou tellst me that which I would fain forget,
Or wish I had not known. If thou wilt humour me
Tell me she's fair and honest.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Yes, and loves you.

lg.l: To forget that, were to exclude the rest:
All saving that, were nothing. Come let's enter.

sp.speaker: 1. draw
sp.p: You are welcome gentlemen. Show them into the next room there.

sp.speaker: 2. draw
sp.p: Look out a towel, and some rolls, a salt and trenchers.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: No sir, we will not dine.

lg.l: I am sure ye would if ye had my stomach.
What wine drink ye, sack or claret?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Where's Bess?

sp.speaker: 2. draw
sp.p: Marry above with three or four gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Go call her.

sp.speaker: 2. D.
sp.p: I'll draw you a cup of the neatest wine in Plymouth

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.p: I'll taste none of your drawing. Go call Bess.

sp.speaker: 2 draw
sp.p: There's nothing in the mouths of these gallants, but Bess, Bess.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: What sa'y sir?

sp.speaker: 2. draw
sp.p: Nothing sir, but I'll go call her presently.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Tell her who's here.

sp.speaker: 2. draw
sp.p: The devil rid her out of the house for me.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Sa'y sir?

sp.speaker: 2 draw
sp.p: Nothing but anon anon sir.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: See she's come.

lg.l: Sweet Mr. Spencer, you're a stranger grown,
Where have you been these three days?
The last night
If ate up late, at game: here take this bag,
And lay't up till I call for't.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Sir I shall.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Bring me some wine.

lg.l: I know your taste,
And I shall please your palate.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Troth 'tis a pretty soul.

lg.l: To thee I will unbosom all my thoughts,
Were her low birth but equal with her beauty
Here would I fix my thoughts.
You are not mad sir?
You say you love her.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Never question that.

lg.l: Then put her to't, win opportunity,
She's the best bawd: if (As you say) she loves you,
She can deny you nothing.
I have proved her
Unto the utmost test. Examined her.
Even to a modest force: but all in vain:
She'll laugh, confer, keep company, discourse,
And something more, kiss: but beyond that compass
She no way can be drawn.
'Tis a virtue,
But seldom found in taverns.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: 'Tis of the best graves wine sir.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Gramercy girl, come sit.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Pray pardon sir, I dare not.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: I'll ha' it so.

lg.l: My fellows love me not, and will complain
Of such a saucy boldness.
Pox on your fellows,
I'll try whether their pottle pots or heads
Be harder, if I do but hear them grumble.
Sit: now Bess drink to me.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: To your good voyage.

sp.speaker: 2 draw
sp.p: Did you call sir?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Yes sir, to have your absence. Captain, this health.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Let it come sir.

sp.speaker: 2 draw
sp.p: Must you be set, and we wait, with a —

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: What say you sir?

sp.speaker: 2 draw
sp.p: Anon, anon, I come there.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: What will you venture Bess to sea with me?

lg.l: What I love best, my heart: for I could wish
I had been born to equal you in fortune,
Or you so low, to have been ranked with me,
I could have then presumed boldly to say,
I love none but my Spencer.
Bess I thank thee.
Keepe still that hundred pound till my return
From th'islands with my lord: if never, wench
Take it, it is thine own.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: You bind me to you.

sp.speaker: 1 draw
sp.p: Bess, you must fill some wine into the portcullis, the gentlemen there will drink none but of your drawing.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: She shall not rise sir, go, let your master snick-up.

sp.speaker: 1 D.
sp.p: And that should be cousin-german to the hiccup.

sp.speaker: 2 draw
sp.p: Bess, you must needs come, the gentlemen fling pots, pottles, drawers, and all down stairs. The whole house is in an uproar.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Pray pardon sir, I needs must be gone.

lg.l: The gentlemen swear if she come not up to them
They will come down to her.
If they come in peace,
Like civil gentlemen, they may be welcome:
If otherwise, let them usurp their pleasures.
We stand prepared for both.
Save you gallants, we are somewhat bold to press
Into your company. It may be held scarce manners,
Therefore fit that we should crave your pardon.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Sir, you are welcome, so are your friends.

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.p: Some wine.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Pray give me leave to fill it.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: You shall not stir. So please you we'll join company. Drawer, more stools.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I take't that's a she drawer. Are you of the house?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: I am sir.

sp.speaker: Caroll.
sp.p: In what place?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: I draw.

sp.speaker: Caroll.
sp.p: Beer, do you not? You are some tapstress.

lg.l: Sir, the worst character you can bestow
Upon the maid is to draw wine.
She would draw none to us,
Perhaps she keeps a roundlet for your taste,
Which none but you must pierce.

sp.speaker: 2 Capt.
sp.p: I pray be civil.

lg.l: I know not, gentlemen, what your intents be,
Nor do I fear or care. This is my room,
And if you bear you, as you seem in show,
Like gentlemen, sit and be sociable.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: We will. Minx, by your leave: remove I say.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: She shall not stir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: How sir?

lg.l: No sir: could you outface the devil,
We do not fear your roaring.
Though you may be companion with a drudge,
It is not fit she should have place by us.
About your business, housewife.
She is worthy
The place as the best here, and she shall keepe.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You lie.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: The gentleman's slain, away.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: O heaven, what have you done?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Undone thyself and me too. Come away ▪

lg.l: O sad misfortune, I shall lose him ever.
What, are you men or milk sops? Stand you still
Senseless as stones, and see your friend in danger
To expire his last?

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.p: Tush, all our help's in vain.

lg.l: This is the fruit of whores.
This mischief came through thee ▪

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: It grew first from your incivility.

lg.l: Lend me a hand to lift his body hence.
It was a fatal business.
One call my master, another fetch the constable,
Here's a man killed in the room.

sp.speaker: 2 drawer
sp.p: How, a man killed sayest thou. Is all paid?

sp.speaker: 1 drawer
sp.p: How fell they out, canst thou tell?

sp.speaker: 2 drawer
sp.p: Sure about this bold Betrice: 'tis not so much for the death of the man, but how shall we come by our reckoning?

lg.l: What shall become of me! Of all lost creatures
The most infortunate. My innocence
Hath been the cause of blood, and I am now
Purpled with murder, though not within compass
Of the law's severe censure: but which most
Adds unto my affliction, I by this
Have lost so worthy and approved a friend,
Whom to redeem from exile, I would give
All that's without and in me.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: Your name's Bess Bridges?

lg.l: An unfortunate maid.
Known by that name too well in Plymouth here.
Your business, sir, with me?

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: Know you this ring?

lg.l: I do: it is my Spencer's.
I know withal you are his trusty friend,
To whom he would commit it. Speak, how fares he?
Is he in freedom, know ye?
He's in health
Of body, though in mind somewhat perplexed
For this late mischief happened.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Is he fled, and freed from danger?

lg.l: Neither. By this token
He lovingly commends him to you Bess,
And prays you when 'tis dark meet him o'th ho
Near to the new-made fort, where he'll attend you,
Before he flies, to take a kind farewell.
There's only Goodlack in his company,
He entreats you not to fail him.
Tell him from me, I'll come, I'll run, I'll fly,
Stand death before me: were I sure to die.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: You are too full of passion.

lg.l: Canst thou blame me,
To have the guilt of murder burden me,
And next, my life in hazard to a death
So ignominious: last, to lose a love
So sweet, so fair, so amorous, and so chaste,
And all these at an instant? Art thou sure
Carol is dead?
I can believe no less.
You hit him in the very speeding place.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: O but the last of these sits nearest my heart.

lg.l: Sir be advised by me.
Try her before you trust her. She perchance
May take th'advantage of your hopeful fortunes:
But when she finds you subject to distress
And casualty, her flattering love may die:
Your deceased hopes.

sp.speaker: Spenc.

lg.l: Thou counsel'st well.
I'll put her to the test and utmost trial
Before I trust her further. Here she comes.

sp.stage: Enter Forset, and Bess with a bag.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: I have done my message sir.

lg.l: Fear not sweet Spencer, we are now alone,
And thou art sanctuaried in these mine arms.
While these confer we'll sentinel their safety.
This place I'll guard.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: I this.

lg.l: Are you not hurt?
Or your skin razed with his offensive steel?
How is it with you?
Bess, all my afflictions
Are that I must leave thee: thou knowest withal
My extreme necessity, and that the fear
Of a most scandalous death doth force me hence.
I am not near my country, and to stay
From new supply from thence, might deeply engage me
To desperate hazard.
Is it coin you want?
Here is the hundred pound you gave me late,
Use that, beside what I have stored and saved
Which makes it fifty more: were it ten thousand
Nay, a whole million, Spencer, all were thine.
No, what thou hast keep still, 'tis all thine own.
Here be my keys, my trunks take to thy charge:
Such gold fit for transportage as I have,
I'll bear along: the rest are freely thine,
Money, apparel, and what else thou findst,
Perhaps worth my bequest and thy receiving,
I make thee mistress of.
Before I doted,
But now you strive to have me ecstasied.
What would you have me do, in which to express
My zeal to you?
Which in my chamber hangs,
My picture, I enjoin thee to keep ever,
For when thou partest with that, thou losest me.
My soul may from my body be divorced,
But never that from me.
I have a house in foy, a tavern called
The windmill, that I freely give thee too,
And thither if I live I'll send to thee.
So soon as I have cast my reckonings up,
And made even with my master, I'll not fail
To visit foy in Cornwall. Is there else
Ought that you will enjoin me?
Thou art fair,
join to thy beauty virtue. Many suitors
I know will tempt thee: beauty's a shrewd bait,
But unto that if thou add'st chastity,
Thou shalt o'ercome all scandal. Time calls hence,
We now must part.
O that I had the power to make time lame,
To stay the stars, or make the moon stand still,
That future day might never haste thy flight.
I could dwell here for ever in thine arms.
And wish it always night.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: We trifle hours. Farewell.

lg.l: First take this ring:
'Twas the first token of my constant love
That passed betwixt us. When I see this next,
And not my Spencer, I shall think thee dead:
For till death part thy body from thy soul
I know thou wilt not part with it.
Swear for me Bess: for thou mayst safely do't.
Once more farewell: at foy thou shalt hear from me.
There's not a word that hath a parting sound
Which through mine ears shrills not immediate death.
I shall not live to lose thee.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: Best be gone, for hark I hear some tread.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: A thousand farewells are in one contracted. Captain away.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: O, I shall die.

lg.l: What mean you Bess, will you betray your friend,
Or call my name in question? Sweet, look up.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Ha, is my Spencer gone?

lg.l: With speed towards Foy,
There to take ship for Fiall.

sp.speaker: Bess.

lg.l: Let me recollect myself,
And what he left in charge. Virtue and chastity.
Next, with all sudden expedition
prepare for foy: all these will I conserve,
And keep them strictly, as I would my life.
Plymouth farewell: in Cornwall I will prove
A second fortune, and for ever mourn,
Until I see my Spencer's safe return.

sp.stage: A dumb Show. Enter general, captains, the mayor: petitioners the other way with papers: amongst these the drawers. The general gives them bags of money. All go off saving the two drawers.

sp.speaker: 1 draw
sp.p: 'Tis well yet we have gotten all the money due to my master. It is the commonest thing that can be for these captains to score and to score: but when the scores are to be paid, non est inventus.

sp.speaker: 2 draw
sp.p: 'Tis ordinary amongst gallants nowadays , who had rather swear forty oaths, then only this one oath, God let me never be trusted.

sp.speaker: 1 draw
sp.p: But if the captains would follow the noble mind of the general, before night there would not be one score owing in Plymouth.

sp.speaker: 2 draw
sp.p: Little knows Bess that my master hath got in these desperate debts: but she hath cast up her account ▪ and is gone.

sp.speaker: 1 draw
sp.p: Whither canst thou tell?

sp.speaker: 2 draw
sp.p: They say to keep a tavern in foy, and that m. Spencer hath given her a stock to set up for herself. Well, howsoever, I am glad, though he killed the man we have got our money.

sp.speaker: Forset.
sp.p: In your time have you seen a sweeter creature?

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: Some week or thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: And in that small time she hath almost undone all the other taverns. The gallants make no rendezvous now but at the windmill.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: Spite of them I'll have her. It shall cost me the setting on but I'll have her.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: Why, do you think she is so easily won?

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: Easily or not, I'll bid as fair and far as any man within twenty miles of my head, but I will put her to the squeak.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: They say there are knights sons already come as suitors to her.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: 'Tis like enough, some younger brothers, and so I intend to make them.

sp.speaker: F●s.
sp.p: If these doings hold, she will grow rich in short time.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: There shall be doings that shall make this windmill my grand seat, my mansion, my palace, and my Constantinople.
sp.stage: Enter Bess bridges like a mistress, and Clem.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: Here she comes: observe how modestly she bears herself.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: I must know of what burden this vessel is, I shall not bear with her till she bear with me, and till then, I cannot report her for a woman of good carriage.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Your old master that dwelled here before my coming, hath turned over your years to me.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Right forsooth: before he was a vintner, he was a shoemaker, and left two or three turn-overs more besides myself.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: How long hast thou to serve.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: But eleven years next grass, and then I am in hope of my freedom. For by that time I shall be at full age.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: How old art thou now?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Forsooth newly come into my teens. I have scraped trenchers this two years, and the next vintage I hope to be bar-boy.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: What's thy name?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: My name is Clem, my father was a baker, and by the report of his neighbours, as honest a man as ever lived by bread.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: And where dwelled he?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Below here in the next crooked street, at the sign of the leg. He was nothing so tall as I, but a little wee-man, and somewhat hunchbacked.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: He was once constable?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: He was indeed, and in that one year of his reign, I have heard them say, he bolted and sifted out more business, than others in that office in many years before him.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: How long is't since he died?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Marry the last dear year. For when corn grew to be at an high rate, my father never dowed after.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: I think I have heard of him.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Then I am sure you have heard he was an honest neighbour, and one that never loved to be meal-mouthed.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Well sirrah, prove an honest servant, and you shall find me your good mistress. What company is in the Marmaid?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: There be four sea captains. I believe they be little better than pirates, they are so flush of their ruddocks.

lg.l: No matter, we will take no note of them.
Here they vent many brave commodities,
By which some gain accrues. They're my good customers,
And still return me profit.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Wot you what mistress, how the two sailors would have served me, that called for the pound and half of cheese?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: How was it Clem?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: When I brought them a reckoning, they would have had me to have scored it up. They took me for a simple gull indeed, that would have had me to have taken chalk for cheese:

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Well, go wait upon the captains, see them want no wine.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Nor reckoning neither, take my word mistress.

lg.l: She's now at leisure, I'll to her.
Lady, what gentlemen are those above?
Sir they are such as please to be my guests,
And they are kindly welcome.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: Give me their names.

lg.l: You may go search the church-book where they were christened.
There you perhaps may learn them.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: Minion, how?

lg.l: Fie, fie, you are too rude with this fair creature,
That no way seeks t'offend you.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Pray hands off.

lg.l: I tell thee maid, wife, or whate'er thou beest,
No man shall enter here but by my leave.
Come, let's be more familiar.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Alas goodman.

lg.l: Why knowest thou whom thou slight'st. I am Roughman,
The only approved gallant of these parts,
A man of whom the roarers stand in awe,
And must not be put off.
I never yet heard man so praise himself,
but proved in'th end a coward.
Coward, Bess?
You will offend me, raise in me that fury
Your beauty cannot calm. Go to, no more,
Your language is too harsh and peremptory.
Pray let me hear no more on't. I tell thee
That quiet day scarce passed me these seven years
I have not cracked a weapon in some fray,
And will you move my spleen?

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: What, threat a woman?

lg.l: Sir, if you thus persist to wrong my house,
Disturb my guests, and nightly domineire,
To put my friends from patience, I'll complain,
And right myself before the magistrate.
Can we not live in compass of the law,
But must be swaggered out on't?
Go too, wench,
I wish thee well, think on't, there's good for thee
Stored in my breast, and when I come in place
I must have no man to offend mine eye:
My love can brook no rivals. For this time
I am content your captains shall have peace,
But must not be used to't.
Sir if you come like other free and civil gentlemen
You're welcome, otherwise my doors are barred you.
That's my good girl,
I have fortunes laid up for thee: what I have
Command it as thine own. Go too, be wise.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Well, I shall study for't.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: Consider on't. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Bes.

lg.l: My mind suggests me that this prating fellow
Is some notorious coward. If he persist
I have a trick, to try what metal's in him.

sp.p: What news with you?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I am now going to carry the captains a reckoning.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: And what's the sum?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Let me see, eight shillings and six pence.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: How can you make that good? write them a bill.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I'll watch them for that, 'tis no time of night to use our bills, the gentlemen are no dwarves, and with one word of my mouth, I can tell them what is to be-tall.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: How comes it to so much?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Imprimis, six quarts of wine at seven pence the quart, seven sixpences.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Why dost thou reckon it so?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Because as they came in by hab nab, so I will bring them in a reckoning at six and at sevens.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Well, wine — 3 s, 6 d.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: And what wants that often groats?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: 'Tis two pence over.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Then put six pence more to it, and make it 4 s, wine, though you bate it them in their meat.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Why so I prithee?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Because of the old proverb, what they want in meat, let them take out in drink. Then for twelve pennyworth of anchoves, 18 d.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: How can that be?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Marry very well mistress, 12 d. anchoves, and 6 d. oil and vinegar. Nay they shall have a saucy reckoning

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: And what for the other half crown?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Bread, beer, salt, napkins, trenchers, one thing with another, so the summa totalis is — 8 s, 6 d.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Well, take the reckoning from the bar.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: What needs that forsooth? The gentlemen seem to be high flown already, send them in but another pottle of sack, and they will cast up the reckoning of themselves. Yes, I'll about it.

lg.l: Were I not with so my suitors pestered,
And might I enjoy my Spencer, what a sweet
Contented life were this? For money flows
And my gain's great. But to my ▪ Roughman next:
I have a trick to try what spirit's in him,
It shall be my next business: in this passion
For my dear Spencer, I propose me this,
Amongst many sorrows some mirth's not amiss,

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: What were you thinking sir?

lg.l: Troth of the world, what any man should see in't
To be in love with it.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: The reason of your meditation.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: To imagine that in the same instant that one forfeits all his estate, another enters upon a rich possession: as one goes to the church to be married, another is hurried to the gallows to be hanged, the last having no feeling of the first man's joy, nor the first of the last man's misery. At the same time that one lies tortured upon the rack, another lies tumbling with his mistress over head and ears in down and feathers. This when I truly consider, I cannot but wonder why any fortune should make a man ecstasied.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: You give yourself too much to melancholy.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: These are my maxims, and were they as faithfully practised by others, as truly apprehended by me, we should have less oppression, and more charity.
sp.stage: Enter the two captains that were before.

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.p: Make good thy words.

sp.speaker: 2 Capt.
sp.p: I say thou hast injured me.

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.p: Tell me wherein.

lg.l: When we assaulted Fiall,
And I had by the generals command
The onset, and with danger of my person
Enforced the Spaniard to a swift retreat,
And beat them from their fort, thou when thou sawest
All fear and danger past, madest up with me
to share that honour which was sole mine own,
And never ventured shot for't, or ere came
Where bullet grazed.
See captain a fray towards,
Let's if we can atone this difference.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Content.

lg.l: I'll prove it with my sword,
That though thou hadst the foremost place in field,
And I the second, yet my company
Was equal in the entry of the fort.
My sword was that day drawn as soon as thine,
And that poor honour which I won that day
Was but my merit.
Wrong me palpably
And justify the same?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: You shall not fight.

lg.l: Why sir, who made you first a justicer,
And taught you that word shall? you are no general,
Or if you be, pray show us your commission.
Sir you have no commission but my counsel,
And that I'll show you freely.

sp.speaker: 2 Capt.
sp.p: 'Tis some chaplain,

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.p: I do not like his text.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Let's beat their weapons down.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: I'll aim at him that offers to divide us!

lg.l: Pox of these part-frays, see I am wounded
By beating down my weapon.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: How fares my friend?

lg.l: You sought for blood, and gentlemen you have it,
Let mine appease you, I am hurt to death.
My rage converts to pity, that this gentleman
Shall suffer for his goodness.
Noble friend,
I will revenge thy death.
He is no friend
That murmurs such a thought. O gentlemen.
I killed a man in Plymouth, and by you
Am slain in Fiall, carol fell by me,
And I fall by a Spencer. Heaven is just,
And will not suffer murder unrevenged,
Heaven pardon me, as I forgive you both,
Shift for yourselves: away.
We saw him die,
But grieve you should so perish.
Note heaven's justice,
And henceforth make that use on't. I shall faint.
Short farewells now must serve. If thou survivest
Live to thine honour: but if thou expir'st
Heaven take thy soul to mercy. Exeunt.
I bleed much,
I must go seek a surgeon.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Sir how cheer you?

lg.l: Like one that's bound upon a new adventure
To th' other world: yet thus much worthy friend
Let me entreat you, since I understand
The fleet is bound for England, take your occasion
To ship yourself, and when you come to foy
Kindly commend me to my dearest Bess,
Thou shalt receive a will, in which I have
Possessed her of five hundred pounds a year.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: A noble legacy.

lg.l: The rest I have bestowed amongst my friends,
Only reserving a bare hundred pounds
To see me honestly and well interred.
I shall perform your trust as carefully
As to my father, breathed he.
Mark me captain:
Her legacy I give with this proviso,
If at thy arrival where my Bess remains,
Thou findst her well reported, free from scandal,
My will stands firm: but if thou hearest her branded
For loose behaviour, or immodest life,
what she should have, I here bestow on thee,
It is thine own: but as thou lovest thy soul
Deal faithfully betwixt my Bess and me.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Else let me die a prodigy.

lg.l: This ring was hers, that, be she loose or chaste,
Being her own, restore her, she will know it,
And doubtless she deserves it. O my memory,
What had I quite forgotten? She hath my picture,

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: And what of that?

lg.l: If she be ranked amongst the loose and lewd,
Take it away, I hold it much undecent,
A whore should have't in keeping: but if constant
Let her enjoy it: this my will perform
As thou art just and honest.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Sense else forsake me.

sp.speaker: Spenc.

lg.l: Now lead me to my chamber, all's mads even,
My peace with earth, and my atone with heaven.

sp.stage: Enter Bess bridges like a page with a sword, and Clem.

lg.l: But that I know my mother to be chaste,
I'd swear some soldier got me.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: It may be many a soldier's buff jerkin came out of your father's tan-fat.

lg.l: Methinks I have a manly spirit in me
In this man's habit.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Now am not I of many men's minds, for if you should do me wrong, I should not kill you, though I took you pissing against a wall.

lg.l: Methinks I could be valiant on the sudden:
And meet a man i'th field.
I could do all that I have heard discoursed
Of Mary Ambree or Westminster's Long-meg.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: What Mary Ambree was I cannot tell, but unless you were taller you will come short of long Meg ▪

lg.l: Of all thy fellows thee I only trust,
And charge thee to be secret.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I am bound in my indentures to keep my master's secrets, and should I find a man in bed with you, I would not tell.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Be gone sir, but no words as you esteem my favour.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: But mistress, I could wish you to look to your long seams, fights are dangerous. But am not I in a sweet taking think you?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: I prithee why?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Why, if you should swagger and kill anybody , I being a vintner should be called to the bar.

lg.l: Let none condemn me of modesty,
Because I try the courage of a man
Who on my soul's a coward: beats my servants,
Cuffs them, and as they pass by him kicks my maids,
Nay domineers over me, making himself
Lord o'er my house and household. Yesternight
I heard him make appointment on some business
To pass alone this way. I'll venture fair,
But I will try what's in him.
Sir, I can now no further, weighty business
Calls me away.
Why at your pleasure then,
Yet I could wish that ere I passed this field,
That I could meet some Hector, so your eyes
Might witness what myself have oft repeated,
Namely that I am valiant.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: Sir no doubt. But now I am in haste. Farewell,

lg.l: How many times brave words bear out a man?
For if he can but make a noise, he's feared.
To talk of frays, although he ne'er had heart
To face a man in field, that's a brave fellow,
I have been valiant I must needs confess,
in street and tavern, where there have been men
Ready to part the fray: but for the fields
They are too cold to fight in.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: You are a villain, a coward, and you lie.

lg.l: You wrong me I protest. Sweet courteous gentleman
I never did you wrong.
Wilt tell me that?
Draw forth thy coward sword, and suddenly,
Or as I am a man I'll run thee through,
And leave thee dead ith' field.
Hold as you are a gentleman. I have ta'en an oath
I will not fight today.
Thou'st took a blow already and the lie,
Will not both these enrage thee?
No, would you give the bastinado too,
I will not break mine oath.
O, your name's Roughman.
No day doth pass you but you hurt or kill.
Is this out of your calendar?
Ay, you are deceived,
I ne'er drew sword in anger I protest,
Unless it were upon some poor weak fellow
That ne'er wore steel about him.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Throw your sword.

lg.l: Here sweet young sir, but as you are a gentleman,
Do not impair mine honour.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Tie that shoe.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: I shall sir.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Untruss that point.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: Any thing this day to save mine oath.

lg.l: Enough: yet not enough, lie down
Till I stride o'er thee.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: Sweet sir any thing.

lg.l: Rise, thou hast leave. Now Roughman thou art blessed
This day thy life is saved, look to the rest.
Take back thy sword.
O you are generous: honour me so much
As let me know to whom I my owe life.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: I am Bess bridges. brother,

sp.speaker: Roug.
sp.p: Still methought that you were something like her.

lg.l: And I have heard,
You domineer and revel in her house,
Control her servants, and abuse her guests,
Which if I ever shall hereafter hear,
Thou art but a dead man.
She never told me of a brother living,
But you have power to sway me.
But for I see you are a gentleman,
I am content this once let you pass,
But if I find you fall into relapse,
The second's far more dangerous.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: I shall fear it. Sir will you take the wine?

lg.l: I am for London.
And for these two terms cannot make return ▪
But if you see my sister, you may say
I was in health.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: Too well, the devil take you.

lg.l: Pray use her well, and at my coming back
I'll ask for your acquaintance. Now farewell.
None saw't he's gone for London: I am unhurt,
Then who shall publish this disgrace abroad?
One man's no slander, should he speak his worst,
My tongue's as loud as his, but in this country
Both of more fame and credit. Should we contest
I can outface the proudest. This is then
My comfort: Roughman, thou art still the same,
For a disgrace not seen, is held no shame.
Aboard, aboard, the wind stands fair for England,
The ships have all weighed anchor.

sp.speaker: 2 Sail.
sp.p: A stiff gale blows from the shore.

lg.l: The sailors call aboard, and I am forced
To leave my friend now at the point of death,
And cannot close his eyes. Here is the will,
Now may I find yond tanners daughter turned
Unchaste or wanton, I shall gain by it
Five hundred pounds a year: here is good evidence.

sp.speaker: 1 sailor.
sp.p: Sir will you take the long boat and aboard?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: 3 Sail.
sp.p: What are you ready mates?

lg.l: We stayed for you. Thou canst not tell who's dead?
The great bell rung out now.
They say 'twas for one Spencer, who this night
Died of a mortal wound.
My worthy friend.
Unhappy man that cannot stay behind
To do him his last rights. Was his name Spencer?
Yes sir, a gentleman of good account
And well known in the navy.
This is the end of all mortality:
It will be news unpleasing to his Bess.
I cannot fair amiss, but long to see
Whether these lands belong to her or me.
Nay fear not sir, now you have scaped this dressing
My life for yours.

sp.speaker: Spen●.
sp.p: I thank thee honest friend.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.p: Sir I can tell you news.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: What is't I prithee?

lg.l: There is a gentleman one of your name,
That died within this hour.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: My name? what was he, of what sickness died he?

lg.l: No sickness, but a sleight hurt in the body,
Which showed at first no danger, but being searched,
He died at the third dressing.
At my third search I am in hope of life.
The heavens are merciful.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.p: Sir doubt not your recovery.

lg.l: That hundred pound I had prepared t'expend
Upon mine own expected funeral
I for name's sake will now bestow on his.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.p: A noble resolution.

lg.l: What ships are bound for England, I would gladly
Venture to sea, though weak.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.p: All bound that way are under sail already.

lg.l: Here's no security,
For when the beaten Spaniards shall return,
They'll spoil whom they can find.
We have a ship,
Of which I am surgeon, that belongs unto
A London merchant, now bound for Mamorah
A town in Barbary, please you to use that,
You shall command free passage: ten months hence
We hope to visit England.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Friend I thank thee.

lg.l: I'll bring you to the master, who I know
Will entertain you gladly.
When I have seen the funeral rights performed
To the dead body of my country man
And kinsman, I will take your courteous offer.
England no doubt will hear news of my death,
How Bess will take it is to me unknown:
On her behaviour I will build my fate,
There raise my love, or thence erect my hate.
O you're well met, just as I prophesied
So it fell out.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: As how I pray?

lg.l: Had you but stayed the crossing of one field,
You had beheld a Hector, the boldest Trojan
That ever Roughman met with.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: Pray what was he?

lg.l: You talk of little Davy, cutting Dick,
And divers such, but tush, this hath no fellow.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: Of what stature and years was he?

lg.l: Indeed I must confess he was no giant,
Nor above fifty, but he did bestir him,
Was here and there, and everywhere at once,
That I was ne'er so put to't since the midwife
First wrapped my head in linen. Let's to Bess.
I'll tell her the whole project.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: Here's the house, we'll enter if you please.

lg.l: Where be these drawers, rascals I should say?
That will give no attendance.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Anon, anon sir, please you see a room. What you here again? Now we shall have such roaring.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: You sirrah call your mistress.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Yes sir, I know it is my duty to call her mistress.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: See and the slave will stir.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Yes I do stir.

lg.l: Shall we have humours, sauce box, you have ears
I'll teach you pricksong.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: But you have now a wrong sow by the ear. I will call her,

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: Do sir, you had best.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: If you were twenty roughmans, if you lug me by the ears again, I'll draw.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: Ha, what will you draw?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: The best wine in the house for your worship: and I would call her, but I can assure you she is either not stirring, or else not in cafe.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: How not in case?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I think she hath not her smock on, for I think I saw it lie at her bed's head.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: What, drawers grow capricious?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Help, help.

lg.l: What uproar's this? shall we be never rid
From these disturbances?
Why how now Bess? Is this your housewifry?
When you are mine I'll have you rise as early as the lark,
Look to the bar yourself: these lazy rascals
Will bring your stare behind hand.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: You lie sir?

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: How? lie?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Yes sir at the raven in the High-street, I was at your lodging this morning for a pottle pot.

lg.l: You will about your business, must you hear
Stand gaping and idle?
You wrong me sir,
And tyrannize too much over my servants.
I will have no man touch them but myself.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: If I do not put ratsbane into his wine in stead of sugar, say I am no true baker.

lg.l: What, rise at noon?
A man may fight a tall fray in a morning,
And one of your best friends too be hacked and mangled,
and almost cut to pieces, and you fast
Close in your bed, ne'er dream on't.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Fought you this day?

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: And ne'er was better put to't in my days.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: I pray, how was't?

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: Thus: as I passed yond fields:

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I pray forsooth, what shall I reckon for the jolle of ling in the portcullis.

lg.l: A pox upon your jolles, you kitchen-stuff,
Go scour your skillets, pots, and dripping-pans,
And interrupt not us.
The devil take your oxheels, you foul
Codshead, must you be kicking?

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: Minion dare you scold?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Yes sir, and lay my ladle over your coxcomb.

lg.l: I do not think that thou dar'st strike a man,
That swagger'st thus o'er women.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: How now Bess?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Shall we be never quiet?

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: You are too rude.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: Now I profess all patience.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Then proceed.

lg.l: Rising up early, minion whilst you slept,
To cross you field, I had but newly parted
With this my friend, but that I soon espied
A gallant fellow, and most strongly armed.
In the mid-field we met, and both being resolute,
We justled for the wall.

sp.speaker: Bess
sp.p: Why, did there stand a wall in the mid-field?

lg.l: I meant strove for the way.
Two such brave spirits meeting, straight both drew.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: The maid forsooth sent me to know whether you would have the shoulder of mutton roasted or sod.

sp.speaker: Roughm.
sp.p: A mischief on your shoulders.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: That's the way to make me never prove good porter

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: You still heap wrongs on wrongs.

lg.l: I was in fury
To think upon the violence of that fight,
And could not stay my rage.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: Once more proceed.

lg.l: O had you seen two tilting meteors justle
In the mid region, with like fear and fury
We two encountered. Not Briareus
Could with his hundred hands have struck more thick.
Blows came about my head, I took them still.
Thrusts by my sides twixt body and my arms,
Yet still I put them by.
When they were past he put them by. Go on.
But in this fury what became of him?
I think I paid him home, he's soundly mauled,
I bosomed him at every second thrust.

sp.speaker: Bess
sp.p: Scaped he with life?

lg.l: 〈◊〉, that's my fear: if he recover this,
I'll never trust my sword more.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Why fly you not if he be in such danger?

lg.l: Because a witch once told me
I ne'er should die for murder.
I believe thee,
But tell me pray, was not this gallant fellow,
A pretty fair young youth about my years?

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: Even thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: He was not fifty then.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Much of my stature?

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: Much about your pitch.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: He was no giant then.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: And wore a suit like this?

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: I half suspect.

lg.l: That gallant fellow,
So wounded and so mangled, was myself,
You base white-livered slave, it was this shoe
that thou stooped to untie: untrust those points:
And like a beastly coward lay along,
Till I strid over thee. Speak, was't not so?

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: It cannot be denied.

lg.l: Hare hearted fellow, milksop, dost not blush?
Give me that rapier: I will make thee swear,
Thou shalt redeem this scorn thou hast incurred,
Or in this woman shape I'll cudgel thee,
And beat thee through the streets. As I am Bess, I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: Hold, hold; I swear.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Dare not to enter at my door till then.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: Shame confounds me quite.

lg.l: That shame redeem: perhaps we'll do thee grace
I love the valiant, but despise the base.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Will you be kicked sir?

lg.l: She hath wakened me,
And kindled that dead fire of courage in me,
Which all this while hath slept: to spare my flesh
And wound my fame, what is't? I will not rest
Till by some valiant deed I have made good
All my disgraces past. I'll cross the street,
And strike the next brave fellow that I meet.

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: I am bound to see the end on't.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: Are you sir?
sp.stage: Enter mayor of Foy, an alderman; and servant.

lg.l: Believe me sir, she bears herself so well,
No man can justly blame her: and I wonder
Being a single woman as she is,
And living in an house of such resort,
She is no more dist●ted.
The best gentlemen
The country yields, become her daily guests.
Sure sir I think she's rich.
Thus much I know, would I could buy her state
Were't for a brace of thousands.
'Twas said a ship is now put into harbour,
Know whence she is.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I'll bring news from the key.

lg.l: To tell you true sir, I could wish a match
Betwixt her and mine own and only son,
And stretch my purse too upon that condition.

sp.speaker: Alderman
sp.p: Please you I'll motion it.

lg.l: One of the ships is new come from the islands,
The greatest man of note's one captain Goodlack.
It is but a small vessel.
I'll meet you straight at th' windmill.
Not one word of my name.

sp.speaker: 1 Sail.
sp.p: We understand you.

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.p: Sir 'tis told us you came late from th'islands ▪

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: I did so:

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.p: Pray sir the news from thence.

lg.l: The best is, that the general is in health,
And Fiall won from th' Spaniards: but the fleet
By reason of so many dangerous tempests
Extremely weather-beaten. You sir I take it,
Are mayor o'th town.

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.p: I am the King's lieutenant.

lg.l: I have some letters of import from one
A gentleman of very good account,
That died late in the islands, to a maid
That keeps a tavern here.

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.p: Her name Bess bridges?

lg.l: The same. I was desired to make inquiry
What fame she bears, and what report she's of.
Now you sir being here chief magistrate,
Can best resolve me.
To our understanding,
She's without stain or blemish well reputed,
And by her modesty and fair demeanour,
Hath won the love of all.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: The worse for me.

lg.l: I can assure you many narrow eyes
Have looked on her and her condition,
But those that with most envy have endeavoured
To entrap her, have returned won by her virtues.
So all that I inquire of make report.
I am glad to hear't. Sir I have now some business,
And I of force must leave you.

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.p: I entreat you to sup with me tonight .

sp.speaker: Goodl.

lg.l: Sir I may trouble you.
Five hundred pound a year out of my way.
Is there no flaw that I can tax her with,
To forfeit this revenue? Is she such a saint,
None can missay her? why then I myself
Will undertake it. If in her demeanour
I can but find one blemish, stain or spot,
It is five hundred pound a year well got.

sp.stage: Enter Clem and the sailors on the one side, at the other Roughman, who draws upon them, and beats them off.
Enter Bess, Clem, and the sailors.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: But did he fight it bravely?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I assure you mistress most dissolutely: he hath run this sailer three times through the body, and yet never touched his skin.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: How can that be?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Through the body of his doublet I meant.

lg.l: How shame, base imputation, and disgrace
Can make a coward valiant: sirrah you
Look to the bar.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I'll hold up my hand there presently.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I understand, you came now from the islands,

sp.speaker: 1 sailor
sp.p: We did so.

lg.l: If you can tell me tidings of one gentleman
I shall requite you largely.

sp.speaker: 1 sailor.
sp.p: Of what name?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: One Spencer.

sp.speaker: 1 sailor.
sp.p: We both saw and knew the man.

lg.l: Only for that call for what wine you please.
Pray tell me where you left him.

sp.speaker: 2 sailor.
sp.p: In Fiall.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Was he in health? how did he fare?

sp.speaker: 2 Sail.
sp.p: Why well.

lg.l: For that good news, spend, revel, and carouse,
Your reckning's paid beforehand. I'm ecstasied,
And my delights unbounded.

sp.speaker: 1 sailor
sp.p: Did you love him?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Next to my hopes in heaven.

sp.speaker: 1 sailor
sp.p: Then change your mirth.

lg.l: Why, as I take it, you told me he was well,
And shall I not rejoice?

sp.speaker: 1 sailor
sp.p: He's well in heaven, for mistress, he is dead,

lg.l: Ha, dead! was't so you said? Thou'st given me, friend
But one wound yet, speak but that word again,
And kill me outright.

sp.speaker: 2 Sail.
sp.p: He lives not.

lg.l: And shall I? Wilt thou not break heart?
Are these my ribs wrought out of brass or steel,
Thou canst not craze their bars?

sp.speaker: 1 sailor
sp.p: Mistress use patience, which conquers all despair.

lg.l: You advise well:
I did but jest with sorrow: you may see
I am now in gentle temper.

sp.speaker: 2 Sail.
sp.p: True, we see't.

lg.l: Pray take the best room in the house, and there
Call for what wine best tastes you: at my leisure
I'll visit you myself.

sp.speaker: 1 sailor
sp.p: I'll use your kindness.

lg.l: That it should be my fate. Poor poor sweetheart
I do but think how thou becomest thy grave,
In which would I lay by thee: what's my wealth
To enjoy't without my Spencer. I will now
Study to die, that I may live with him.
The further I inquire, the more I hear
To my discomfort. If my discontinuance
And change at sea disguise me from her knowledge
I shall have scope enough to prove her fully.
This sadness argues she hath heard some news
Of my friend's death.
It cannot sure be true
That he is dead, death could not be so envious
To snatch him in his prime. I study to forget
That ere was such a man.
If not impeach her,
My purpose is to seek to marry her.
If she deny me, I'll conceal the will,
Or at the least make her compound for half.
Save you fair gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: You are welcome sir.

lg.l: I hear say there's a whore here that draws wine,
I am sharp set, and newly come from sea,
And I would see the trash.
Sure you mistake sir.
If you desire attendance and some wine
I can command you both. Where be these boys?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Are you the mistress?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: I command the house.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Of what birth are you, pray?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: A tanner's daughter.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Where born?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: In Somersetshire.

lg.l: A trade-fallen tanner's daughter go so brave:
O you have tricks to compass these gay clothes.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: None sir, but what are honest.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: What's your name?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Bess Bridges most men call me.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: You're a whore.

lg.l: Sir, I will fetch you wine to wash your mouth,
It is so foul, I fear't may fester else.
There may be danger in't.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Not all this move her patience.

lg.l: Good sir, at this time I am scarce myself
By reason of a great and weighty loss
That troubles me: but I should know that ring.
How, this, you baggage? It was never made
To grace a strumpet's finger.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Pardon sir, I both must and will leave you.

lg.l: Did not this well ▪ this will stick in my stomach
I could repent my wrongs done to this maid:
But I'll not leave her thus: if she still love him.
I'll break her heartstrings with some false report
Of his unkindness.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: You are welcome gentleman: what wine will you drink? Claret, metheglin, or muskadine, cider or perry, to make you merry, Aragoosa's, or Peter-see-me ▪ canary or Charnico? But by your nose sir you should love a cup of malmsey: you shall have a cup of the best in Cornwall.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Here's a brave drawer will quarrel with his wine.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
But if you prefer the Frenchman before the Spaniard, you shall have either here of the deep red grape or the pallid white. You are a pretty tall gentleman, you should love high-country wine: none but clerks and sextons love graves wine. Or are you a maried man, I'll
furnish you with bastard, white or brown, according to the complexion of your bedfellow.

lg.l: You rogue, how many years of your prenticeship
Have you spent in studying this set speech?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: The first line of my part was, anon anon, sir: and the first question I answered to, was loggerhead, or blockhead, I know not whether.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Speak, where's your mistress?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Gone up to her chamber.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Set a pottle of sack in th'fire, and carry it into the next room.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Score a pottle of sack in the crown, and see at the bar for some rotten eggs to burn it: we must have one trick or other to vent away our bad commodities.

lg.l: To die, and not vouchsafe some few commends
Before his death, was most unkindly done.
This picture is more courteous: 'twill not shrink
For twenty thousand kisses: no nor blush:
Than thou shalt be my husband, and I vow
Never to marry other.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Where's this harlot?

lg.l: You are immodest sir to press thus rudely
Into my private chamber.
Pox of modesty
When punks must have it mincing in their mouths.
And have I found thee? then shalt hence with me.
Rob me not of the chiefest wealth I have:
Search all my trunks, take the best jewels there:
Deprive me not that treasure, I'll redeem it
With plate, and all the little coin I have,
So I make keep that still.
Thinkst thou that bribes
Can make me leave my friends will unperformed?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: What was that friend?

lg.l: One Spencer, dead i'th islands,
Whose very last words uttered at his death
Were these, if ever thou shalt come to Foy,
Take thence my picture, and deface it quite:
For let it not be said, my portraiture
Shall grace a strumpet's chamber.
'Twas not so:
You lie, you are a villain: 'twas not so.
'Tis more than sin thus to bely the dead:
He knew if ever I would have transgressed,
'Thad been with him: he dared have sworn me chaste,
And died in that belief.
Are you so brief?
Nay, I'll not trouble you: God bye you.
Yet leave me still that picture, and I'll swear
You are a gentleman, and cannot lie.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: I am inexorable.

lg.l: Are you a christian, have you any name
That ever good man gave you?
'Twas no saint you were called after. What's thy name?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: My name is captain Thomas good —

lg.l: I can see no good in thee ▪ race that syllable
Out of thy name.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Goodlacke's my name.

lg.l: I cry you mercy sir: I now remember you,
You were my Spencer's friend, and I am sorry,
Because he loved you, I have been so harsh:
For whose sake, I entreat ere you take't hence,
I may but take my leave on't.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: You'll return it?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: As I am chaste I will.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: For once I'll trust you.

lg.l: O thou the perfect semblance of my love,
And all that's left of him, take one sweet kiss,
As my last farewell. Thou resemblest him
for whose sweet safety I was every morning
Down on my knees, and with the larks sweet tunes
I did begin my prayers: and when sad sleep
Had charmed all eyes, when none save the bright stars ▪
Were up and waking, I remembered thee,
But all, all to no purpose.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Sure, most sure, this cannot be dissembled.

lg.l: To thee I have been constant in thine absence,
And when I looked upon this painted piece
Remembered thy last rules and principles:
For thee I have given alms, visited prisons,
To gentlemen and passengers lent coin,
That if they ever had ability
They might repay't to Spencer: yet for this,
All this, and more, I cannot have so much
As this poor table.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.p: I should question truth, if I should wrong this creature.

lg.l: I am resolved.
See sir, this picture I restore you back,
Which since it was his will you should take hence,
I will not wrong the dead.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: God be wi'you.

lg.l: One word more.
Spencer you say was so unkind in death:

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: I tell you true.

lg.l: I do entreat you even for goodness' sake
Since you were one that he entirely loved,
If you some few days hence hear me expired,
You will amongst other good men, and poor people
That haply may miss Bess, grace me so much
As follow me to th' grave. This if you promise,
You shall not be the least of all my friends
Remembered in my will. Now fare you well.
Had I a heart of flint or adamant
It would relent at this. My mistress Bess,
I have better tidings for you.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: You will restore my picture? will you?

lg.l: Yes, and more than that,
This ring from my friend's finger sent to you,
With infinite commends.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: You change my blood.

lg.l: These writings are the evidence of lands ▪
Five hundred pound ay ear's bequeathed to you,
Of which I here possess you: all is yours.
This surplusage of love, hath made my loss
That was but great before: now infinite.
It may be compassed: there's in this my purpose
No impossibility.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: What study you?

lg.l: Four thousand pound besides this legacy,
In jewels, gold, and silver I can make,
And every man discharged. I am resolved
To be a pattern to all maids hereafter
Of constancy in love.
Sweet mistress Bess, will you command my service,
If to succeed your Spencer in his love,
I would expose me wholly to your wishes.
Alas my love sleeps with him in his grave,
And cannot thence be wakened: yet for his sake
I will impart a secret to your trust,
Which, saving you, no mortal should partake.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Both for his love and yours, command my service ▪

lg.l: There's a prize
Brought into Falmouth road, a good tight vessel,
The bottom will but cost eight hundred pound,
You shall have money: buy it.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: To what end?

lg.l: That you shall know hereafter. Furnish her
With all provision needful: spare no cost:
And join with you a ging of lusty lads,
Such as will bravely man her: all the charge
I will commit to you: and when she's fit,
captain she is thine own.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: I sound it not.

lg.l: Spare me the rest. This voyage I intend,
Though some may blame, all lovers will ▪ commend.

div.head: Actus quartus. Scaena prima.
div.stage: After an alarmne, enter a Spanish captain, with Saylors, bringing in a merchant, Spencer, and the surgeon prisoners.

lg.l: For fialls loss, and spoil by th'english done,
We are in part revenged. There's not a vessel
That bears upon her top s. George's cross,
But for that act shall suffer.
Insult not Spaniard,
Nor be too proud, that thou by odds of ships,
Provision, men, and powder madest us yield.
Had you come one to one, or made assault
With reasonable advantage; we by this
Had made the carcase of your ship your graves,
Low sunk to the sea's bottom.
Englishman, thy ship shall yield us pillage,
These prisoners we will keep in strongest hold,
To pay no other ransom then their lives ▪
Degenerate Spaniard, there's no noblesse in thee
To threaten men unarmed and miserable,
Thou mightst as well tread o'er a field of slaughter,
And kill them o'er, that are already slain,
And brag thy manhood.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: Sirrah, what are you?

lg.l: Thy equal as I am a prisoner,
But once to stay a better man than thou,
a gentleman in my country.
Wert thou not so, we have strappado, bolts,
And engines to the main-mast-fastened,
Can make you gentle.
Spaniard do thy worst, thou canst not act
More tortures than my courage is able to endure.
These Englishmen
Nothing can daunt them: even in misery
They'll not regard their masters.

sp.speaker: Spenc
sp.p: Masters! Insulting bragging Thrasoes.

sp.speaker: Span.

lg.l: His sauciness we'll punish above the rest.
About their censures we will next devise,

sp.p: And now towards Spain with our brave English prize.
sp.stage: Enter Bess, mayor, alderman, Clem. A table set out, and stools.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: A table and some stools.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: I shall give you occasion to case your tails presently.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Will't please you sit?

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.p: With all our hearts, and thank you.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Fetch me that parchment in my closet window.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: The three sherp skins with the wrong side outward

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: That with the seal.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I hope it is my indenture, and now she means to give me my time.

lg.l: And now you are alone, fair mistress Elizabeth
I think it good to taste you with a motion.
That no way can displease you.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Pray speak on.

lg.l: 'T hath pleased here master mayor so far to look
Into your fair demeanour that he thinks you
A fit match for his son.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Here's the parchment, but if it be the lease of your house, I can assure you 'tis out.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: The years are not expired.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: No, but it is out of your closet.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: About your business.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Here's even Susanna betwixt the two wicked elders.

sp.speaker: Alderman
sp.p: What think you mistress Elzabeth?

lg.l: Sir I thank you.
And how much I esteem this goodness from you
The trust I shall commit unto your charge
Will truly witness. Marry, gentle sir!
Alas I have sadder business now in hand,
Then sprightly marriage, witness these my tears.
Pray read there.

sp.speaker: Mayor.
sp.p: The last will and testament of Elzabeth bridges to be committed to the trust of the mayor and aldermen of foy, and their successors for ever.

lg.l: To set up young beginners in their trade, a thousand pound
To relieve such as have had loss by sea, 500 pound.
To every maid that's married out of Foy,
Whose name's Elzabeth ten pound.
To relieve maimed soldiers, by the year ten pound.
To captain Goodlack, if he shall perform
The business he's employed in, five hundred pound.
The legacies for Spencer thus to stand,
To number all the poorest of his kin,
And to bestow on them. Item to —
Enough: you see sir I am now too poor
To bring a dowry with me fit for your son.
You want a precedent, you so abound
In charity and goodness.
All my servants
I leave at your discretions to dispose
Not one but I have left some legacy.
What shall become of me, or what I purpose
Spare further to inquire.
We'll take our leaves.
And prove to you faithful executors.
In this bequest.
Let never such despair,
As dying rich, shall make the poor their hair.
Why what is all the wealth the world contains.
Without my Spencer?
Where's my sweet Bess?
Shall I become a welcome suitor now?
That I have changed my copy?
I joy to hear it.
I'll find employment for you.
A gallant ship, and wondrous proudly trimmed,
Well calked, well tackled, every way prepared.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Here then our mourn for a season end.

lg.l: Bess, shall I strike that captain? say the word,
I'll have him by the ears.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Not for the world.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: What saith that fellow?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: He desires your love, good, captain let him ha' it.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Then change a hand.

lg.l: Resolve me all. I am bound upon a voyage,
Will you in this adventure take such part,
As I myself shall do?

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: With my fair Bess, to the world's end.

lg.l: Then captain and lieutenant both, join hands,
Such are your places now.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: We two are friends.

lg.l: I next must swear you two, 〈◊〉 all your ging
True to some articles you must observe,
Reserving to myself a prime command,
Whilst I enjoin nothing unreasonable.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: All this is granted.

lg.l: Then first, you said your ship was trim and gay
I'll have her pitched all o'er, no spot of white,
No colour to be seen, no sail but black,
No flag but sable.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: 'Twill be ominous, and bode disaster fortune.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: I'll ha' it so.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Why then she shall be pitched black as the devil,

lg.l: She shall be called the negro, when you know
My conceit, captain, you will thank for't.

sp.speaker: Roug.
sp.p: But whither are we bound?

lg.l: Pardon me that.
When we are out at sea I'll tell you all.
For mine own wearing I have rich apparel,
For man or woman as occasion serves.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: But mistress, if you be going to sea, what shall become of me a land.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: I'll give thee thy full time.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: And shall I take time, when time is, and let my mistress slip away. No, it shall be seen that my teeth are as strong to grind biscuit as the best sail or of them all, and my stomach as able to digest powdered beef and poor-john. Shall I stay here to see scoare a pudding in the half-moon, and see my mistress at the 〈◊〉 yard with her sails up, and spread. No it shall be seen that I who have been brought up to draw wine, will see what water the ship draws, or I'll bewray the voyage.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: If thou hast so much courage, the captain shall accept thee.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: If I have so much courage? When did you see a black beard with a white liver, or a little fellow without a tall stomach. I doubt not but to prove an honour to-all the drawers in Cornwall.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: What now reimains?

sp.speaker: Fors.
sp.p: To make myself associate in this bold enterprise.

lg.l: Most gladly sir.
And now our number's full, what's to be done.

sp.speaker: Bess.

lg.l: First, at my charge I'll feast the town of foy,
then set the cellars open, that these my mates
May quaff unto the health of our boon voyage,
Our needful things being once conveyed aboard,
Then casting up our caps in sign of joy.
Our purpose is to bid farewell to Foy.

sp.stage: Enter Mullisheg Basham Alcade, and Joffer: with other attendants.

lg.l: Out of these bloody and intestine broils
We have at length attained a fortunate peace,
And now at last established in the throne
Of our great ancestors, and reign King
Of Fez and great Morocco.
Mighty Mullisheg,
Pride of our age, and glory of the Moors,
By whose victorious hand all Barbary
Is conquered, awed, and swayed: behold thy vassals
With loud applauses greet thy victory.
Upon the slaughtered bodies of our foes,
We mount our high tribunal, and being sole
Without competitor, we now have leisure
To establish laws first for our kingdom's safety,
The enriching of our public treasury,
And last our state and pleasure: then give order
That all such Christian merchants as have traffic
And freedom in our country, that conceal
The least part of our custom me due to us,
Shall forfeit ship and goods.
There are appointed
Unto that purpose careful officers.
Those forfeitures must help to furnish up
Th'exhausted treasure that our wars consumed,
Part of such profits as 〈◊〉 that way
We have already tasted.
'Tis most fit,
Those Christians that reap profit ▪ by our land
Should contribute unto so great a loss.
Alcade, they shall. But what's the style of King,
Without his pleasure? Find us concubines,
The fairest Christian damsels you can hire,
Or buy for gold: the loveliest of the Moors
We can command, and negroes everywhere ▪
Italians, French, and Dutch, choice Turkish girls
Must fill our alkedavy, the great palace,
Where Mullisheg now deigns to keep his court.
Who else are worthy to be libertines,
But such as bear the sword?

sp.speaker: Mull.

lg.l: Joffer, thou pleasest us.
If Kings on earth be termed demigods.
Why should we not make here terrestrial heaven?
We can, we will, our God shall be our pleasure,
For so our Meccan prophet warrants as.
And now the music of the drums surcease,
We'll learn to dance to the soft tunes of peace.

sp.stage: Enter Bess like a sea-captain, Goodlacke, Roughman, forset, and Clem.

lg.l: Good morrow captain. O this last sea-sight
Was gallantly performed. It did me good
To see the Spanish carvel veil her top
Unto my maiden flag. Where ride we now?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Among the islands.

sp.speaker: Boss.
sp.p: What coast is this we now descry from far.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Yond fort's called Fiall.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Is that the place where Spencer's body lies?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Yes, in yond church he's buried.

lg.l: Then know, to this place was my voyage bound
To fetch the body of my Spencer thence.
In his own country to erect a tomb ▪
And lasting monument, where when I die
In the same bed of earth my bones may lie
Then all that love me ▪ arm and make for shore,
Yours be the spoil, he mine, I crave no more.
May that man die derided and accursed
That will not follow where a woman leads.
Roughwan, you are too rash, and counsel ill,
Have not the Spaniards fortified the town?
In all our ging we are but sixty five.

sp.speaker: Rough●.
sp.p: Come, I'll make one.

lg.l: Attend me good lieutenant.
And sweet Bess, listen what I have devised,
With ten tall fellows I have maned our boat,
To see what straggling spaniards they can take.
And see where Forset is returned with prisoners.
These Spaniards we by break of day surprised,
As they were ready to take beat for fishing.
Spaniards, upon your lives resolve us truly
How strong's the town and fort.
Since English Raleigh won and spoiled it first,
The town's re-edified and fort new built,
And four field-pieces in the block house lie
To keep the harbours mouth.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: And what's one ship to these ▪

lg.l: Was there not in the time of their abode
A gentleman called Spencer buried there
Within the church, whom some report was slain,
Or perished by a wound?
Indeed there was,
And o'er him raised a goodly monument,
But when the English navy were failed thence,
And that the Spaniards did possess the town.
Because they held him for an heretic,
They straight removed his body from the church.
And would the tyrants be so uncharitable
To wrong the dead? where did they then bestow him?

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: They buried him ith' fields.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: O still more cruel.

lg.l: The man that ought the field, doubtful his corn
Would never prosper whilst an heretic's body
Lay there, he made petition to the church
To ha' it digged up and burned, and so it was.
What's he that loves me would persuade me live.
Not rather leap o'er hatches into th'sea:
Yet ere I die I hope to be revenged
Upon some Spaniards for my Spencer's wrong.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: Let's first begin with these.

lg.l: Alas these poor slaves! besides their pardoned lives
One give them money. And Spaniards where you come,
Pray for Bess bridges, and speak well o'th English.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: We shall.

lg.l: Our mourning we will turn into revenge,
And since the church hath censured so my Spencer,
Bestow upon the church some few cast pieces,
Command the gunner do't.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: And if he can to batter it to the earth.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: A sail, a sail.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: From whence?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: A pox upon yond gunner, could he not give warning before he had shot?

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: Why I prithee?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Why? I was sent to the topmast to watch, and there I fell fast asleep. Bounce quoth the guns, down tumbles Clem, and if by chance my feet had not hung in the tackles, you must have sent to England for a bonesetter, for my neck had been in a pitiful taking,

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: Thou toldst us of a sail.

lg.l: Arm gentlemen, a gallant ship of war
Makes with her full sails this way: who it seems
Hath taken a bark of England.
Which we'll rescue.
Or perish in th'adventure. You have sworn
That howsoe'er we conquer or miscarry
Not to reveal my sex.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We have.

lg.l: Then for your country's honour, my revenge,
For your own fame, and hope of golden spoil,
Stand bravely to't. The manage of the fight
We leave to you.
Then now up with your fights, and let your ensigns
Blessed with s. George's cross, play with the winds.
Fair Bess, keep you your cabin.
Captain you wrong me, I will face the fight,
And where the bullets sing loudest about mine ears,
There shall you find me cheering up my men.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: This wench would of a coward make an Hercules.

lg.l: Trumpets a charge, and with your whistles shrill
Sound boatswains an alarum to your mates.
With music cheer up their astonisht souls,
The whilst the thundering ordnance bear the base.
To fight against the Spaniards we desire ▪
Alarm trumpets.

sp.speaker: Rough.
sp.p: Gunners straight give fire.
sp.stage: Enter Goodlacke hurt. Bess, Roughman, Forset, Clem.

lg.l: I am shot and can no longer man the deck,
Yet let not my wound daunt your courage mates.

sp.speaker: Bess.

lg.l: For every drop of blood that thou hast shed,
I'll have a Spaniards life. Advance your targets,
And now cry all, board, board, amain for England.

sp.stage: Enter with victory Bess, Roughman, Forset, Clem. etc. the Spaniards prisoners.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: How is it with the captain?

lg.l: Nothing dangerous,
But being shot ith' thigh he keeps his cabin ▪
And cannot rise to greet your victory.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: He stood it bravely out whilst he could stand.

lg.l: But for these Spaniards, now you don Diego's,
You that made Paul's to stink.
Before we further censure them, let's know
What English prisoners they have here aboard.
You may command them all. We that were now
Lords over them, fortune hath made your slaves,
Release our prisoners.
Had my captain died
Not one proud Spaniard had escaped with life,
Your ship is forfeit to us, and your goods.
So live. Give him his long boat: him and his
Set safe ashore; and pray for English Bess.

sp.speaker: Sp.

lg.l: I know not whom you mean, but be't your Queen
Famous Elizabeth, I shall report
She and her subjects both are merciful.

sp.stage: Enter Roughman, with the merchant and Spencer.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Whence are you sir? and whither were you bound?

lg.l: I am a London bound for Barbary,
But by this Spanish man-of-war surprised,
Pillaged and captived.
We much pity you,
What love you have sustained, this Spanish prey
Shall make good to you to the utmost farthing ▪
Our lives, and all our fortunes whatsoever
Are wholly at your service.
These gentlemen have been dejected long,
Let me peruse them all, and give them money
to drink our health, and pray forget not sirs,
To pray for — hold, support me, or I faint ▪
What sudden unexpected ecstasy
Disturbs your conquest.
Interrupt me not,
But give me way for heaven's sake.
I have seen a face ere now like that young gentleman,
But not remember where.
But he was slain,
Lay buried in yond church, and thence removed,
Denied all Christian rights, and like an infidel
Confined unto the fields, and thence digged up,
His body after death had martyrdom:
All these assure me 'tis his shadow dogs me,
For some most just revenge ▪ thus far to sea.
Is it because the Spaniards scaped with life,
That were to thee so cruel after death
Thou hauntest me thus? Sweet ghost thy rage forbear,
I will revenge thee on the next we seize.
I am amazed, this sight I'll not endure.
Sleep, sleep, fair ghost, for thy revenge is sure.

sp.speaker: Roug.
sp.p: Forset, convey the owner to his cabin.

sp.speaker: Spencer.
sp.p: I pray sir what young gentleman is that?

lg.l: He's both the owner of the ship and goods,
That for some reasons hath his name concealed.
